win. As iI Is oi little consequence with which of these men the inquiry first begins, will propose few queries to your cor respondent relating particularly to the sub- ject which he appears to have under se- consideration and thereby, directing his attention to the precise point, will enable him to get along faster in his discussion- to preserve proper degree of consistency in his communcation, and at the same time do ample justice to this important sub ject.

 Was Mr. Sterling representative in Congress immediately prior to the election of MT. Merwin? Was Mir. Merwin mem- Der of the Legislature of this State when a caucus, composed of Legislative members, placed his name upon the congressional nomination? Was Mir. Sterling superseded by the nomination of Mir. Merwin! Did MT. Merwin personally solicit such nomi- nation at the expence of Mir. Sterling, or any other man? Did !le manage, and in- trigue, to obtain it! Did he assure any member, or number of members, of that caucus, that if he could be elected to Con- gress at that time, that he would be per- fectly satisfed-would never ask, or ex- pect, re-election-would never interfere any further claim upon his party, and would ever afier remain perfectly satisfied Did MT. Merwin have the delicacy to give this pledge personality Were any of the members of our last State caucus also mem- bers of that caucus that displaced MT. Ster- ling-and did it so happen that this pledge had been given them Did any of them at the last caucus vote for MT. Merwin, or did they consider MT. Merwin and his friends as playing a double game? Does Mir. Merwin and his friends wish to create scism and discord in the party to which he and they profess to belong? Does Mir. Merw;n expect that the stale cry of FAR MFRS aducrSus think the term is LAW YERs is to raise whirlwind upon which he is to ride, and from which he is to guide the storm?

 It is expected that your correspondent will truly answer the above questions; & in due time, if he wishes to pursue the in- vestigation, he may be furnished with a few more queries relating to the private as we'll as the political life of his friend, Mir. Merwin. And also, as profess to pre- serve strict neutrality between both these gentlemen, your correspondent may rest assured that when the investigation into Mir. Mcrwin's life is completed, we will take up that of Mir. Sterling, and ascertain, if possible, which is chaff and which wheat.

 KENT.

MT. SMITH,

 Sir-I perceive by several communica- tions in your paper, that war has com menced between the friends eff MT. Mer- win and MT. Ansel Sterling. Now as it regards the political party to which these gentlemen belong, it is very much mat ter of indifference which of them is elected to the next Congress except in this one particular,- us have the one which is the most honest. Either of them know enough to discharge the ordinary duties that may devolve upon them but if either of them is knave, no one could repose a confidence in him. A writer in the Post of the 18th inst. has commenced person. al attack upon Mir. Sterling, and this, un- der all circumstances, is altogether proper. I trust he will fearlessly'' persue the course he has adopted-the community expect at his hands statement of facts susceptible of procf relative to both tho poe Iitical and private life of Mir. Sterling, which will eviuce to the public that he is unworthy their suhrages--display before us his vices, his private and political sins and foIlies-i. c. if he has been guilty of any. And it is expected also that this cor respondent of yours will pursue tue same impartial course with respect ,o Mr. Mer-

As you will have perceived, nothing was done yesterday in the Senate of any import ance-ifI I except the appointment of the Bank rupt Bill as the special order of the day for Monday, and debate upon raising the salary of the Post Master General which will doubt less succeed. In the House, the battle is still carried on upon the subject of revolutionary compcnsations. MT. Webstergave yesterday one of his powerful speeches on this subject. To-day MT. Wicklife took the floor at an early hour, and advanced an argument simi- lar to that which noticed in my last, with considerable vehemence. He was followed by MT. Test, of I, d. who spoke at great length against the bill. He condemned it as partial in its allotment Ofthe recommendations which it contemplated, and as giving to the officers a greater proportion of the sum than theywere entitled to. He thought that the country were equally indebted to the militia as to the regulars, and to the privates as to the officers; but he would not allow that the United States owed debt to these men. If it was debt ofgrattude that was meant, then it was true the debt was boundIess. But the men of the revolution fought for glory, forindependence, and not for mercenary reward. If it was in those who served, he should be in favour of

 

 ward all according to their merits, he thought the distribution of what we could give should be equally dispensed to all. Besides, he com pIained that the bill did not discriminate as to the condition of the officers There might be some aboundinG in wealth-and to them he would not give but show him a poor officer of the revolution, and as far as his influence went, that man should be shielded from want during the remainder ofhis days. MT Clark, of Ky. next took the floor. He argued upon the point, that the heirs of the deceased revo- lutiOnary soldiers were also entitled to the compensation, as well as the survivors, and urged his ideas with very strong statements and deductions. Still must object to this course of reasoning: because, if it prevails,by throwing a mountain of expenditures in the way, it will defeat the object of the bill. MT. Sprague of Me. followed in nearly the same strain; but no question was taken before ad- jOurnment.

 attended the annual meeting of the Colo nization Society, this morning. The meeting was thin, but great number of members of Congress, in proportion to the whole. were present. Mir. Clay was among the audience; but on the account of the absence of many of the members, occasiOned by the failure of notification, after the Report had been read, the meeting was postponed to Saturday next.

 Not one word, as yet, from MT. Calhoun's Committee. You may have seen communi- cation in the Journal, signed " Young Rife." which was doubtless written by Satterlee Clark, as he is the person, who, as is there in- sinuated, was bullied, in order to bring him to the ultimatum of duel. The bully is said to be gallant Colonel. elevated by Mir. Calhoun to an office in the Department of War.

 There is much solid business now upon the hands of both houses of Congress. Thus far, contrary to anticipation, little has been done in public affairs; but a much greater number than usual of private matters have been des- patched.

 Mr Msllary OfVtgave notice that he should on "Wednesday next, ask the House to go into Committee of the Whole on the hill proposing

In Northfeld, on the 10th inst. MT. Julius Todd to Miss Caroline A. Bassett.

 In Warren, by the Rev. Charles A. Board man, MT. Reuel Cogswel, jun. to Miss Eliza Weed.

 DIED.

 in Northfeld, on the 4th inst. Widow Mar tha Curtiss aged 94.

 In WatertOwn, N. Y. on the 7th inst. Mrs. Ann Benedict, aged 40, relict of Amos Bene- dict, Esq. Mrs. B. was the daughter of Capt. James Stone. and a native of this village. Although it is several years since she resided with us, her friends and acquaintance never have forgot the lovely character she sustained, nor ceased to admire the tender, delicate, and affectionate disposition she manifested, her unyielding principles of integrity; and the dis eliminating powers of her mind, and above all her exemplary christian character.

 In Fairfield, on the 16th inst. MT. George Alexander Mills. in the 21st year of his age, late a Cadet in Capt. Partridge's Military A. cademy, and a young man of superior talents and promise.

 In Hartford, suddenly on Sunday evening, the l4th inst. Capt. John Hampstead, Sur veyor of the Port of Hartford, in the esd year of his age; Mrs. Anna Goodwin, aged 65.

 In Lebanon, Col. James Clark, aged 96, well known as having distinguished himself at the battle of fBunker's Hill, and in other revO- lutiOnary services.

 In Springfield, Mass. while sitting in his chair, Harrison Gray Otis, Jr, Esq. of BOs- ton.

ue tN' |. papers or Iast nigtIt, contaln no further intelligence of the war with Spain: indeed they state that there had been no new arrivals since last week.

 FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE.

 The advices from Odessa. relative to the War between Russia and Persia were increa:. sing in interest. The Russians had fought. several battles with the natives, but, although in all these engagements, the advantages were on the side of his Imperial Majesty. yet in each succeeding engagement the bravery of the Persians became more conspicuous, and the farther the invaders proceeded, the more certain was considered their ultimate de- struction.

 A very serious disturbance commenced in ConstantinOple on the 2Gd of October. The Grand Scignior, at whose court. it appears, the most accomplished diplomatists of Europe are at present assembled, began on the QQd, and up to the 26th, when the Maltese vessel sailed, he had put to death, or rather legitim- ateIy executed, upwards of 5000 of his sub jects. The shops of the Turks were general ly closed, and the most gloomy forebodings entertained by those whOleither actually then were, or hereafter might be, considered hos tile to his Sublime Highness.

 On the 9th of July fire broke out in Batavia, which destroyed one hundred and eighty houses, and property to asconsiderable amount.

 The news from Greece is generally of a more favorable aspect. A great number of the inhabitants of Romelia had rebelled a. gainst the Porte. Lord Cochrane has left Marseilles for Leglorn. His Lordship, tho distressed and irritated by the delays in the construction and equipment of the steam ves- sels. and all the fraudulent proceedings of in- dividuals with respect to the Greek loans, is still very far from despairing of the success of the Greek cause, ,er thinking that he cannot effectualy serve it.

engrOSs all the offices, aud usurp all the pow CT. of the county. But it will require some thing besides naked assertions to convince our intelligent farmers, that their neighbOrs, who are united to them by an hundred ties of in- terest, and friendly intercourse, have cOnspi- red to trample down their rights. But what is the proOfl Mir. Sterling,a lawyer, has been nominated to a seat in Congress; and this threatens such danger. that the faithful senti- mel has blown the trumpet Of alarm, four months before the battle. When and where was it, in the legislatures of free countries, that lawyers did not exert an important infu- ence In fact no man can be good legisla- tor, who is not lawyer. Not that he must be practically, and professionally SO. But he must be versed in the laws, and the constitu- tion of our country else how can he improve them by legislation. The physician must un- derstand the nature of the disease, in order to know what remedy to administer. know it is important that men of all occupations, and professions, should compose our legislatures i; so that the interests of every class in society may he duly attended to in the business of le- gislation. The farmers wish to be represent ed by farmer for this reason, and no other They want man who will watch over, and spare n" efforts to advance the agricultural in- terests of the country. Now sir Mir. Sterling is d farmer a practical farmer. By far the greater portion of his time is occupied with the labours of his farm. He ever has been, and will be, the guardian of the farmers inter- est, because it is his interest. His interests will he therefore identified with those of his con- stitueHts, as well as those of Mr.. MerWin. And he has this immense advantage over him. he knows better how to promote those inter- csts. But while urge upon the farmers of the county the claims of MT. Sterling, I would not he understood as admitting that those claims have been questioned by them. The combination which has been formed to put down this gentleman, is not composed of far mcrs as a body, but of restless intri ouers who are cndeavOurng to create a prc. Iudice against him, because he has the misfortune to he a lawyer. Eow stainless must that mans reputation be, against whom his enemies can find no other cause of reproach, than that he is a distinguished member of an honorable profession But the writer have above noti- ccd insinuates. that have been induced to ad- NOcate the cause of cabal, which by the way does not exist, by "the promise of patronage and prcferment." How prone are those who are conscious of being actuated by unworthy motives, to imputc them to others. Suspi- cion rarely dwells in the bosom of innocence. Will that writer deny, that he is united to the man whose cause he SO warmly cspouses, by one of the closest ties which can bind men to- Srther. The allusjon may seem personal; should have suppressed it, had it not been call ed forth by wanton, an unwarrantable, and base attack, which he has made upon the mor- al character of Mir. Sterling. He has accu- sed him of dishonesty. of being insincere in the principles which he professes. As this imputation rests on assertion alone, shall not at present assume the unnecessary task of proving negative. only insist that in the character of defender of the innocent and 'lnjustly accused, should be justified not on ly in repelling the charges hut in exposing its author; even in disclosing his name if I thought proper. I have right to tear from the assassin his mask, as well as to wreot from him his dagger. But this have not done; I have only shown him by ausions which he can understand, that it is in my power to do SO; and he has reason to thank my forbear- ance and not complain of my severity.

 A REPUBLICAN ELECToR.

 FOR THE COUNTY POST.

 MT. SMITH,

goods.

 On motion of Mr. White of Florida, the Committee on Commerce was instructed to inquire into the expectancy of providing for the better regulation of Collection Dis tricts in the Territory of Florida, and of the expedency of removing the Port of Entry from the AppilachicOla to St Marks.

 A letter from Washington of the 14th inst. thus speaks Ofthe probability of the bankrupt act being passed at this session.

 Ut is believed that therei is now fair pros pect that that most desirable measure of uniform national Bankrupt Law, will at last be passed A little concession on the part of the members from the commercial States, in yielding to the clause called voluntary bank ruptcy,"by which, persons who are not mer- chants, may submit to commission, as is provided in the new English Bankrupt Law, would probably secure it's passage. The de- cision of the Supreme Court upon the validity of the state insolvent laws, may have some effect. That question is to be argued in few days, and much may depend on its determin alton. It was argued in 1894, but has been continued ever since for deiiberatiOn, and is now to be re-argutd, in consequence of Judge Trimbe taking his seat on the Bench, he having been appointed since the former hear ing"

 18th CONGRESS-. .......2d SESSION. Monday Jan. IS. Among the many petitions presented this day was one by Mir. Warrington, from citizens of Mary land, praying an appropriation in aid of polar expedition.

 On motion of MT. Crump, it was RcsOlved, That the committee on revo- lutionary claims be instructed to inquire into the expediency of allowing compen- sation to Peter Francisco, of Buckingham county, Virginia, for horse shot unddr the said Francisco, during the revolution ary war.

 A resolution submitted by MT. Lawrence, on Thursday, relative to the estimate for the repair and preservation ofthe Cumber- land road, was taken up and agreed to. MT. Miner submitted a resolution re- specting the public buildings, which after debate, was laid on the table. The house then resumed discussion of the bill to provide for the officers and sol- diers of the army of the revolution.

 The question being on the motion ofMr. Wickliffe to amend Messrs. Weems, Everett and Living ston, spoke at considerable length against the amendment, which was finally agreed to-ayes 1O1, nose 88. The house then adjourned. Tuesday, Jan. 16. After the reception of several reports | from the different committees, The house resumed the bill to provide for the surviving officers of the army of the revolution.

 MT. Whittlesey said he had voted with the Majority yesterday, and he was now requested to move for reconsideration of the vote by which the amendment of the gentlemen from Kentucky had been adop- ted. It was due to himself, however to state, that he should still vote for the a. mendment, from the conviction, that if a debt was due to the officers of the revolu- ton, it was equally due to the heirs and representatives of those who had died. He then moved that the house do reconsider it's vote of yesterday.

 On motion of MT. Wright, the ayes and noes were ordered on this question; and there appeared, ayes 7S, noes 96. So the question was determined in the negative.

 MT. Woods then moved to lay the bill on the table.

 On motion of MT. Burges, the ayes and noes were ordered-and the question being taken, there were, ayes 76, noes 1O9; so the motion was negatived. The question being then on concurring with the committee of the whole in its a. mendment,

 MT. Burgess rose for the purpose of mo- wing that the house go into committee of the whole in order to increase the appropri- ation, for if the amendment of the gentle man from Kentucky was adopted, the pitt tance for each individual would be so small as to render the bill entirely useless.

 The division of the question was called for.

 The question being on the committed of the bill, MT. Buchanan arose, and after other remark said he had risen to ask, if, after going into committee of the whole, it would be competent to move to amend the bill by striking out the amendment of the gentleman from Kentucky. If SO, on the principle that while there is life, there is hope, he would vote in favor of going into committee.

 The Speaker decided that it would be

for rccOmmitting the bill 97 and opposed % votes, so the bill was then committed to the committee of the whole and made the order of the day tomorrow.

 "Wednesday, Jan. 17. 1 After numerous reports,

 Mir. Bartlett from the committee on na- val affairs, who were instucted to inquire into the expedicncy of making such alter aGons and improvements as the public ser- 1 wee may require in the medical department ot the navy, made a report in detail there- on; which was read and laid on the table. ] The report considers certain alterations advisable, but suggest that they are already before the house.

 ] The bill from the house of representa- tives to set apart township of land, for the support of seminary of learning in Arkansas, was read twice by unanimous consent, and referred.

 MT. Weems moved the following reso- lution

 ResOlved, That a special committee be appointed by this house to inquire into the expediency of making an appropriation for aiding in the transportation ofsuch free people of color as wish to be sent to Afri- ca, or elswhere, without the limits of the United Statets.

 l On the question, twill the house now consider this resolution ?'' it was decided in the negative.

 | A letter was received from the secreta- ] ry of the treasury, on the sub ject ofsheep's wool, which was committed to the com- mittee of the whole on the new tariff MT. Burges moved that the house re- solve itself into committee of the whole, on the bill for the relief of the surviving officers of the revolutionary war but, by majority ofthrce or four votes, the house refused to resolve itself into a committee of the whole on the bill

 On motion of MT. Mallery, the house then resolved itself into the committee of the whole on the state of the union, (3O votes to 59,) Mr.. Buchanan in the chair, and took up the bill, "f,r the alteration of the acts imposing duties on imports.'' 1 Friday, Jan. 19.

 In the Senate, MT. Harrison, by unan- imous consent, introduced joint resolu- tion for $1O,OOO to the indigent sufferers by the late fire in Alexandria, to be put in the hands of the Mayor of that city for distribution; which was read twice, con- sidered and discussed in the Committee of the Whole, and then referred to the Com mittee on the District of Columbia. After spending an hour or two in the considera- ton of Executive business, tic Senate ad journed over to Monday.

 | A message was received from the Pres ident by the House of Representatives, communicating report from the Secreta- ry of State, ,and the correspondence between Mir. Clay and Chevalier Hugeons, on the subject of discriminating duties eXacted in the Netherlands, ,on importations in Amer ican vessels. The message and report are with the Congressional proceedings.

 Fire at Alexandria. On Thursday a. bout 9 o'clock, A. M. fire broke out in this city, which threatened general destruc- ton. The weather was excessively cold (the thermometer at 13)-it ragged for five hours, famed by brisk northwest wind; and, at last, was subdued after destroying about forty houses, besides back-buildings, and other property, in the whole valued at $2OO,OOO. It is thought that thou sand persons from Washington-with the marine corps and persons attached to the navy yard, proceeded with their appara tus, the whole at an average distance of seven miles, to assist in subduing the de. vouring element and it appears that the apparatus they took with them chiefly af- forded the means of arresting the prog ress of the flames. The efficiency of shin- gle roofs to spread a fire, and of hose to prevent its spreading, is said to have been r clearly demonstrated on this awful occa- sion.-NileS.

 We are pleased to learn from the south- ern papers that the legislature of Virginia, mindful of the character of the state, and of the Senate of the U. s. has refused to re-elect John Randolph to the station he so foully disgraced last winter. We do not exult in this, because the " Hero of Roanoke" was member of the "opposi- tion," and Gov. Tyler, his successor, may not be-Gov. Tyler will, we presume, be leader in the opposition ;' but he will not disgrace his country by billingsgate slang, and fiery invective against every thing republican, against every measure which is not purely aristocratical. He isa gentleman-his predecessor was not. MT.

SPRAYED,

 smmnrzess E>ROM the pasture of the A subscriber, sometime last summer, a red yearling HEIF- 1HAA.s FIR, about middling size.with crop off the left ear. No other artificial mark. Whoever will return her. or inform where she may be found shall be suitably rewarded by

 JOSHUA R. LAWTON. Goshen, Jan. 21 1897. S9

NHE Subscribers have procured from the -A Stock of JOHN HARE TOWEL, Esq. of Philadelphia, the full bred IMPROVED SHORT HORNED DURHAM BULL

 WARWICK, which will be kept at the Stable of the sub- scrbers the ensuing season..

 Those persons wishing to improve their breed of Cattle will do well to avail them selves of this opportunity y.-The most promi. nent traits in the character of this breed of Cattle are-the most perfect symetry form great size-rapid growth-unusual aptness to fatten-and great Milkers.

 WARWICK was sired by the very celebra- ted imported Bull, WYE COMET, his dam the imported Cow, BELLE, from the best blood in England-and is himself most beautiful animal.

 E. w. TOWNER, & Co. Goshen, Jan. 22, 1927. Sg

DANIEL STODDARD'S ESTATE. ENHE Hon. Court of Probate for the Dis N trct of Litchfeld has allowed six months from this date, for the Creditors of the estate of

 DANIEL STODDARD, late of Litchfeld, deceased, to present their claims for allowance. All who neglect com plying with this notice will be debarred re- cOvery.

 SOLON BISHOP, Adm'r. N. B.-All persons indebted to said estate are requested to make immediate payment to the administrator.

 Litchfield. Jan. 20, 1927. S2

full articles.headline:
FOR THE COUNTY POST.

Mir. SMITH,,
full articles.article:
MT. SMITH,

 Sir-I perceive by several communica- tions in your paper, that war has com menced between the friends eff MT. Mer- win and MT. Ansel Sterling. Now as it regards the political party to which these gentlemen belong, it is very much mat ter of indifference which of them is elected to the next Congress except in this one particular,- us have the one which is the most honest. Either of them know enough to discharge the ordinary duties that may devolve upon them but if either of them is knave, no one could repose a confidence in him. A writer in the Post of the 18th inst. has commenced person. al attack upon Mir. Sterling, and this, un- der all circumstances, is altogether proper. I trust he will fearlessly'' persue the course he has adopted-the community expect at his hands statement of facts susceptible of procf relative to both tho poe Iitical and private life of Mir. Sterling, which will eviuce to the public that he is unworthy their suhrages--display before us his vices, his private and political sins and foIlies-i. c. if he has been guilty of any. And it is expected also that this cor respondent of yours will pursue tue same impartial course with respect ,o Mr. Mer-

As you will have perceived, nothing was done yesterday in the Senate of any import ance-ifI I except the appointment of the Bank rupt Bill as the special order of the day for Monday, and debate upon raising the salary of the Post Master General which will doubt less succeed. In the House, the battle is still carried on upon the subject of revolutionary compcnsations. MT. Webstergave yesterday one of his powerful speeches on this subject. To-day MT. Wicklife took the floor at an early hour, and advanced an argument simi- lar to that which noticed in my last, with considerable vehemence. He was followed by MT. Test, of I, d. who spoke at great length against the bill. He condemned it as partial in its allotment Ofthe recommendations which it contemplated, and as giving to the officers a greater proportion of the sum than theywere entitled to. He thought that the country were equally indebted to the militia as to the regulars, and to the privates as to the officers; but he would not allow that the United States owed debt to these men. If it was debt ofgrattude that was meant, then it was true the debt was boundIess. But the men of the revolution fought for glory, forindependence, and not for mercenary reward. If it was in those who served, he should be in favour of

 

 ward all according to their merits, he thought the distribution of what we could give should be equally dispensed to all. Besides, he com pIained that the bill did not discriminate as to the condition of the officers There might be some aboundinG in wealth-and to them he would not give but show him a poor officer of the revolution, and as far as his influence went, that man should be shielded from want during the remainder ofhis days. MT Clark, of Ky. next took the floor. He argued upon the point, that the heirs of the deceased revo- lutiOnary soldiers were also entitled to the compensation, as well as the survivors, and urged his ideas with very strong statements and deductions. Still must object to this course of reasoning: because, if it prevails,by throwing a mountain of expenditures in the way, it will defeat the object of the bill. MT. Sprague of Me. followed in nearly the same strain; but no question was taken before ad- jOurnment.

 attended the annual meeting of the Colo nization Society, this morning. The meeting was thin, but great number of members of Congress, in proportion to the whole. were present. Mir. Clay was among the audience; but on the account of the absence of many of the members, occasiOned by the failure of notification, after the Report had been read, the meeting was postponed to Saturday next.

You may have seen communi- cation in the Journal, signed " Young Rife." which was doubtless written by Satterlee Clark, as he is the person, who, as is there in- sinuated, was bullied, in order to bring him to the ultimatum of duel. The bully is said to be gallant Colonel. elevated by Mir. Calhoun to an office in the Department of War.

In Northfeld, on the 10th inst. MT. Julius Todd to Miss Caroline A. Bassett.

 In Warren, by the Rev. Charles A. Board man, MT. Reuel Cogswel, jun. to Miss Eliza Weed.

 DIED.

 in Northfeld, on the 4th inst. Widow Mar tha Curtiss aged 94.

 In WatertOwn, N. Y. on the 7th inst. Mrs. Ann Benedict, aged 40, relict of Amos Bene- dict, Esq. Mrs. B. was the daughter of Capt. James Stone. and a native of this village. Although it is several years since she resided with us, her friends and acquaintance never have forgot the lovely character she sustained, nor ceased to admire the tender, delicate, and affectionate disposition she manifested, her unyielding principles of integrity; and the dis eliminating powers of her mind, and above all her exemplary christian character.

 In Fairfield, on the 16th inst. MT. George Alexander Mills. in the 21st year of his age, late a Cadet in Capt. Partridge's Military A. cademy, and a young man of superior talents and promise.

 In Hartford, suddenly on Sunday evening, the l4th inst. Capt. John Hampstead, Sur veyor of the Port of Hartford, in the esd year of his age; Mrs. Anna Goodwin, aged 65.

 In Lebanon, Col. James Clark, aged 96, well known as having distinguished himself at the battle of fBunker's Hill, and in other revO- lutiOnary services.

 In Springfield, Mass. while sitting in his chair, Harrison Gray Otis, Jr, Esq. of BOs- ton.

ue tN' |. papers or Iast nigtIt, contaln no further intelligence of the war with Spain: indeed they state that there had been no new arrivals since last week.

 FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE.

 The advices from Odessa. relative to the War between Russia and Persia were increa:. sing in interest. The Russians had fought. several battles with the natives, but, although in all these engagements, the advantages were on the side of his Imperial Majesty. yet in each succeeding engagement the bravery of the Persians became more conspicuous, and the farther the invaders proceeded, the more certain was considered their ultimate de- struction.

 A very serious disturbance commenced in ConstantinOple on the 2Gd of October. The Grand Scignior, at whose court. it appears, the most accomplished diplomatists of Europe are at present assembled, began on the QQd, and up to the 26th, when the Maltese vessel sailed, he had put to death, or rather legitim- ateIy executed, upwards of 5000 of his sub jects. The shops of the Turks were general ly closed, and the most gloomy forebodings entertained by those whOleither actually then were, or hereafter might be, considered hos tile to his Sublime Highness.

 On the 9th of July fire broke out in Batavia, which destroyed one hundred and eighty houses, and property to asconsiderable amount.

 The news from Greece is generally of a more favorable aspect. A great number of the inhabitants of Romelia had rebelled a. gainst the Porte. Lord Cochrane has left Marseilles for Leglorn. His Lordship, tho distressed and irritated by the delays in the construction and equipment of the steam ves- sels. and all the fraudulent proceedings of in- dividuals with respect to the Greek loans, is still very far from despairing of the success of the Greek cause, ,er thinking that he cannot effectualy serve it.

engrOSs all the offices, aud usurp all the pow CT. of the county. But it will require some thing besides naked assertions to convince our intelligent farmers, that their neighbOrs, who are united to them by an hundred ties of in- terest, and friendly intercourse, have cOnspi- red to trample down their rights. But what is the proOfl Mir. Sterling,a lawyer, has been nominated to a seat in Congress; and this threatens such danger. that the faithful senti- mel has blown the trumpet Of alarm, four months before the battle. When and where was it, in the legislatures of free countries, that lawyers did not exert an important infu- ence In fact no man can be good legisla- tor, who is not lawyer. Not that he must be practically, and professionally SO. But he must be versed in the laws, and the constitu- tion of our country else how can he improve them by legislation. The physician must un- derstand the nature of the disease, in order to know what remedy to administer. know it is important that men of all occupations, and professions, should compose our legislatures i; so that the interests of every class in society may he duly attended to in the business of le- gislation. The farmers wish to be represent ed by farmer for this reason, and no other They want man who will watch over, and spare n" efforts to advance the agricultural in- terests of the country. Now sir Mir. Sterling is d farmer a practical farmer. By far the greater portion of his time is occupied with the labours of his farm. He ever has been, and will be, the guardian of the farmers inter- est, because it is his interest. His interests will he therefore identified with those of his con- stitueHts, as well as those of Mr.. MerWin. And he has this immense advantage over him. he knows better how to promote those inter- csts. But while urge upon the farmers of the county the claims of MT. Sterling, I would not he understood as admitting that those claims have been questioned by them. The combination which has been formed to put down this gentleman, is not composed of far mcrs as a body, but of restless intri ouers who are cndeavOurng to create a prc. Iudice against him, because he has the misfortune to he a lawyer. Eow stainless must that mans reputation be, against whom his enemies can find no other cause of reproach, than that he is a distinguished member of an honorable profession But the writer have above noti- ccd insinuates. that have been induced to ad- NOcate the cause of cabal, which by the way does not exist, by "the promise of patronage and prcferment." How prone are those who are conscious of being actuated by unworthy motives, to imputc them to others. Suspi- cion rarely dwells in the bosom of innocence. Will that writer deny, that he is united to the man whose cause he SO warmly cspouses, by one of the closest ties which can bind men to- Srther. The allusjon may seem personal; should have suppressed it, had it not been call ed forth by wanton, an unwarrantable, and base attack, which he has made upon the mor- al character of Mir. Sterling. He has accu- sed him of dishonesty. of being insincere in the principles which he professes. As this imputation rests on assertion alone, shall not at present assume the unnecessary task of proving negative. only insist that in the character of defender of the innocent and 'lnjustly accused, should be justified not on ly in repelling the charges hut in exposing its author; even in disclosing his name if I thought proper. I have right to tear from the assassin his mask, as well as to wreot from him his dagger. But this have not done; I have only shown him by ausions which he can understand, that it is in my power to do SO; and he has reason to thank my forbear- ance and not complain of my severity.

 A REPUBLICAN ELECToR.

 FOR THE COUNTY POST.

 MT. SMITH,

goods.

 On motion of Mr. White of Florida, the Committee on Commerce was instructed to inquire into the expectancy of providing for the better regulation of Collection Dis tricts in the Territory of Florida, and of the expedency of removing the Port of Entry from the AppilachicOla to St Marks.

 A letter from Washington of the 14th inst. thus speaks Ofthe probability of the bankrupt act being passed at this session.

 Ut is believed that therei is now fair pros pect that that most desirable measure of uniform national Bankrupt Law, will at last be passed A little concession on the part of the members from the commercial States, in yielding to the clause called voluntary bank ruptcy,"by which, persons who are not mer- chants, may submit to commission, as is provided in the new English Bankrupt Law, would probably secure it's passage. The de- cision of the Supreme Court upon the validity of the state insolvent laws, may have some effect. That question is to be argued in few days, and much may depend on its determin alton. It was argued in 1894, but has been continued ever since for deiiberatiOn, and is now to be re-argutd, in consequence of Judge Trimbe taking his seat on the Bench, he having been appointed since the former hear ing"

 18th CONGRESS-. .......2d SESSION. Monday Jan. IS. Among the many petitions presented this day was one by Mir. Warrington, from citizens of Mary land, praying an appropriation in aid of polar expedition.

 On motion of MT. Crump, it was RcsOlved, That the committee on revo- lutionary claims be instructed to inquire into the expediency of allowing compen- sation to Peter Francisco, of Buckingham county, Virginia, for horse shot unddr the said Francisco, during the revolution ary war.

 A resolution submitted by MT. Lawrence, on Thursday, relative to the estimate for the repair and preservation ofthe Cumber- land road, was taken up and agreed to. MT. Miner submitted a resolution re- specting the public buildings, which after debate, was laid on the table. The house then resumed discussion of the bill to provide for the officers and sol- diers of the army of the revolution.

 The question being on the motion ofMr. Wickliffe to amend Messrs. Weems, Everett and Living ston, spoke at considerable length against the amendment, which was finally agreed to-ayes 1O1, nose 88. The house then adjourned. Tuesday, Jan. 16. After the reception of several reports | from the different committees, The house resumed the bill to provide for the surviving officers of the army of the revolution.

 MT. Whittlesey said he had voted with the Majority yesterday, and he was now requested to move for reconsideration of the vote by which the amendment of the gentlemen from Kentucky had been adop- ted. It was due to himself, however to state, that he should still vote for the a. mendment, from the conviction, that if a debt was due to the officers of the revolu- ton, it was equally due to the heirs and representatives of those who had died. He then moved that the house do reconsider it's vote of yesterday.

 On motion of MT. Wright, the ayes and noes were ordered on this question; and there appeared, ayes 7S, noes 96. So the question was determined in the negative.

 MT. Woods then moved to lay the bill on the table.

 On motion of MT. Burges, the ayes and noes were ordered-and the question being taken, there were, ayes 76, noes 1O9; so the motion was negatived. The question being then on concurring with the committee of the whole in its a. mendment,

 MT. Burgess rose for the purpose of mo- wing that the house go into committee of the whole in order to increase the appropri- ation, for if the amendment of the gentle man from Kentucky was adopted, the pitt tance for each individual would be so small as to render the bill entirely useless.

 The division of the question was called for.

 The question being on the committed of the bill, MT. Buchanan arose, and after other remark said he had risen to ask, if, after going into committee of the whole, it would be competent to move to amend the bill by striking out the amendment of the gentleman from Kentucky. If SO, on the principle that while there is life, there is hope, he would vote in favor of going into committee.

 The Speaker decided that it would be

for rccOmmitting the bill 97 and opposed % votes, so the bill was then committed to the committee of the whole and made the order of the day tomorrow.

 "Wednesday, Jan. 17. 1 After numerous reports,

 Mir. Bartlett from the committee on na- val affairs, who were instucted to inquire into the expedicncy of making such alter aGons and improvements as the public ser- 1 wee may require in the medical department ot the navy, made a report in detail there- on; which was read and laid on the table. ] The report considers certain alterations advisable, but suggest that they are already before the house.

 ] The bill from the house of representa- tives to set apart township of land, for the support of seminary of learning in Arkansas, was read twice by unanimous consent, and referred.

 MT. Weems moved the following reso- lution

 ResOlved, That a special committee be appointed by this house to inquire into the expediency of making an appropriation for aiding in the transportation ofsuch free people of color as wish to be sent to Afri- ca, or elswhere, without the limits of the United Statets.

 l On the question, twill the house now consider this resolution ?'' it was decided in the negative.

 | A letter was received from the secreta- ] ry of the treasury, on the sub ject ofsheep's wool, which was committed to the com- mittee of the whole on the new tariff MT. Burges moved that the house re- solve itself into committee of the whole, on the bill for the relief of the surviving officers of the revolutionary war but, by majority ofthrce or four votes, the house refused to resolve itself into a committee of the whole on the bill

 On motion of MT. Mallery, the house then resolved itself into the committee of the whole on the state of the union, (3O votes to 59,) Mr.. Buchanan in the chair, and took up the bill, "f,r the alteration of the acts imposing duties on imports.'' 1 Friday, Jan. 19.

 In the Senate, MT. Harrison, by unan- imous consent, introduced joint resolu- tion for $1O,OOO to the indigent sufferers by the late fire in Alexandria, to be put in the hands of the Mayor of that city for distribution; which was read twice, con- sidered and discussed in the Committee of the Whole, and then referred to the Com mittee on the District of Columbia. After spending an hour or two in the considera- ton of Executive business, tic Senate ad journed over to Monday.

 | A message was received from the Pres ident by the House of Representatives, communicating report from the Secreta- ry of State, ,and the correspondence between Mir. Clay and Chevalier Hugeons, on the subject of discriminating duties eXacted in the Netherlands, ,on importations in Amer ican vessels. The message and report are with the Congressional proceedings.

 Fire at Alexandria. On Thursday a. bout 9 o'clock, A. M. fire broke out in this city, which threatened general destruc- ton. The weather was excessively cold (the thermometer at 13)-it ragged for five hours, famed by brisk northwest wind; and, at last, was subdued after destroying about forty houses, besides back-buildings, and other property, in the whole valued at $2OO,OOO. It is thought that thou sand persons from Washington-with the marine corps and persons attached to the navy yard, proceeded with their appara tus, the whole at an average distance of seven miles, to assist in subduing the de. vouring element and it appears that the apparatus they took with them chiefly af- forded the means of arresting the prog ress of the flames. The efficiency of shin- gle roofs to spread a fire, and of hose to prevent its spreading, is said to have been r clearly demonstrated on this awful occa- sion.-NileS.

 We are pleased to learn from the south- ern papers that the legislature of Virginia, mindful of the character of the state, and of the Senate of the U. s. has refused to re-elect John Randolph to the station he so foully disgraced last winter. We do not exult in this, because the " Hero of Roanoke" was member of the "opposi- tion," and Gov. Tyler, his successor, may not be-Gov. Tyler will, we presume, be leader in the opposition ;' but he will not disgrace his country by billingsgate slang, and fiery invective against every thing republican, against every measure which is not purely aristocratical. He isa gentleman-his predecessor was not. MT.

full articles.headline: IMPROVED STOCK.
full articles.article:
NHE Subscribers have procured from the -A Stock of JOHN HARE TOWEL, Esq. of Philadelphia, the full bred IMPROVED SHORT HORNED DURHAM BULL

 WARWICK, which will be kept at the Stable of the sub- scrbers the ensuing season..

 Those persons wishing to improve their breed of Cattle will do well to avail them selves of this opportunity y.-The most promi. nent traits in the character of this breed of Cattle are-the most perfect symetry form great size-rapid growth-unusual aptness to fatten-and great Milkers.

 WARWICK was sired by the very celebra- ted imported Bull, WYE COMET, his dam the imported Cow, BELLE, from the best blood in England-and is himself most beautiful animal.

 E. w. TOWNER, & Co. Goshen, Jan. 22, 1927. Sg

DANIEL STODDARD'S ESTATE. ENHE Hon. Court of Probate for the Dis N trct of Litchfeld has allowed six months from this date, for the Creditors of the estate of

 DANIEL STODDARD, late of Litchfeld, deceased, to present their claims for allowance. All who neglect com plying with this notice will be debarred re- cOvery.

 SOLON BISHOP, Adm'r. N. B.-All persons indebted to said estate are requested to make immediate payment to the administrator.

 Litchfield. Jan. 20, 1927. S2
